review.title: Structural Damage Identification Using Artificial Neural Network and Synthetic data
review.abstract: This paper presents real-time vibration based identification technique using measured frequency response functions(FRFs) under random vibration loading. Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) are trained to map damage fingerprints to damage characteristic parameters. Principal component statistical analysis(PCA) technique was used to tackle the problem of high dimensionality and high noise of data, which is common for industrial structures. The present study considers Crack, Rivet hole expansion and redundant uniform mass as damages on the structure. Frequency response function data after being reduced in size using PCA is fed to individual neural networks to localize and predict the severity of damage on the structure. The system of ANNs trained with both numerical and experimental model data to make the system reliable and robust. The methodology is applied to a numerical model of stiffened panel structure, where damages are confined close to the stiffener. The results showed that, in all the cases considered, it is possible to localize and predict severity of the damage occurrence with very good accuracy and reliability.

metadata.title: Structural Damage Identification Using Artificial Neural Network and Synthetic data

sections.text: This year it is so far that it will only take one year to move on to the next round.

sections.heading: 2. Dimensionality Reduction
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 PCA of the Frequency Response Function
sections.text: Principal Uni Component Analysis (PCA) [14], [15] is a statistical method that allows to identify the main directions in which the data vary. A key application of PCA is to reduce the dimensionality of the problem in the case where eigenvalues cover a wide dynamic range. In particular, it allows to identify the main directions in which the data vary. Principal components are completely equivalent to determining the eigenvectors of the covariance matrix: each eigenvector gives a major component. The corresponding eigenvalue represents the variance of this main component, and the main components with the largest deviations are the most important. In order to produce damage indices that are feasible for neural network training, the size of the damage quantities (FRFs) must be greatly reduced. For the stiffened panel structure is a complete FRF structure that covers a frequency range from 0 to 1000 Hz.

sections.heading: 2.2 Damage fingerprint in the reduced FRF
sections.text: Dimensionality reduction using PCA leads to a fingerprint of the damage scenario on the reduced data. Figures 1 below show the main component variation for different damage scenarios. Generally, determining the optimal number of PCs depends on the quality of the damage patterns embedded in a data set, as well as the degree of noise exposure. As a general guideline, indications of dominant features of a data set are provided by individual and cumulative contributions from PCs. For example, if the first 7 PCs account for more than 99% of the information in the original data, selecting more than 7 PCs for damage identification is probably unnecessary as the information gained by including higher PCs is negligible.

sections.heading: 3. Neural Network
sections.text: In fact, it is as if it were a matter of a way in which it is a matter of a system, in which it is a matter of a system, in which it is a matter of a system, in which it is a matter of a system, in which it is a matter of a system.

sections.heading: 4. Damage Identification through Neural Networks
sections.text: The compressed FRF data is transmitted to their respective neural network to determine the location and the severity of the damage. the stiffened panel consists of 34 rivets. The binary vector of the size 34 × 1 characterizes the location of the rivet where the damage occurred. The verified vector with all "0" stands for a healthy structure. The learning algorithm for Bavarian regularization is used for the above neural network. The power diagrams for the neural network crack are captured in Figure 3. The tested power parameter is the mean square error, the best network.The numerical structure (Figure 4), which contains crack, is subject to a random charge time signal, the time response signal of 8 measuring points are transformed into the frequency domain using Fast Fourier transform method to obtain frequency response functions.The huge FRF data is compressed to the main FRF data compressed to the Vexx1 of the network.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: The proposed work dealt with artificial neural networks (ANNs) in vibration-based damage identification and their application in the aerospace industry.The proposed damage identification scheme is based on frequency response functions (FRFs).The method uses neural network techniques and main component analyses for damage trait extraction and reduction. In order to verify the proposed damage identification procedures, numerical studies were conducted on a stiffened panel structure.To overcome the obstacle of the large size of FRF data, the introduction of PCA techniques was proposed. Besides data reduction, PCA also offers the advantage of noise reduction and damage trait extraction, which further helps to reduce uncertainties from sources such as measuring noise and environmental fluctuation.The main component analysis proved to be an efficient technique for compressing the data without loss of information on damage traits to determine the damage traits performance based on the proposed FRF.

referenceMentions.context: network techniques have been applied to structural health monitoring and damage detection[1], [2].
network techniques have been applied to structural health monitoring and damage detection[1], [2].
Kudva [3] used a back propagation neural network to identify damage in a plate stiffened with a 4 x 4 array of bays.
(1992) [4] used a back propagation neural network on a three-story building driven by earthquake excitation.
[5] used feed- forward neural network to identify damage in a steel bridge element.
In a similar study Rhim and Lee (1994)[6] used back propagation neural network to identify delamination damage in a composite cantilever beam.
[7]–[11] present the use of FRF data for damage detection in different types of numerical and experimental structures; in some cases, techniques have been tested on real structures.
[7]–[11] present the use of FRF data for damage detection in different types of numerical and experimental structures; in some cases, techniques have been tested on real structures.
FRF data is one of the easiest to obtain in real time as they require only a small number of sensors and very little human involvement[12].
They provide an abundance of information on the structure dynamic behavior at master degrees of freedom over a range of frequency interest, whereas modal data are only subsets of FRF data [13].
Principal Component Analysis(PCA) [14], [15] is a statistical procedure which allows identifying the principal directions in which the data varies.
Principal Component Analysis(PCA) [14], [15] is a statistical procedure which allows identifying the principal directions in which the data varies.
This research was driven by the desire to build better pattern recognition and information processing system[16].
